Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Machine Assisted Comparative Policy Analysis in Public Health
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to enhance the capabilities of a research tool for companies, legal experts and researchers undertaking nationwide comparative policy analysis in the public health domain. The tool will assist experts in identifying relevant policy documents by determining and scoring the significance of statutory provisions in context of specific legal questions. The quantitative approach can enable novel policy tracking. Rather than experts setting up alerts for updates to a specific set of documents, this tool learns from the legal text used to answer legal questions to allow for real time tracking and discovery of updates and other relevant documents. This approach to policy tracking can present experts with timely information on updates, along with revealing new documents as they are introduced. Timely analysis can inform policy-makers, facilitating the crafting of optimized evidence-based public health legislation. Reducing the cost and effort of the most time-consuming aspects of legal research can make precise scientific policy analysis affordable and accessible commercially and in real time.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will decrease the time required to produce timely analysis of public health policy across 50 states. This research will apply machine learning, natural language processing and graph theory techniques to extract logical legal ontologies by computing similarities of public health provisions in statutory text. In domain specific problems, large sets of examples of annotated text are required. In the legal domain there is little available expert-labeled legal corpora and purposefully curating this kind of dataset is prohibitively expensive. To address this challenge, the proposed solution integrates transparently into legal experts' workflow while generating ontology that mirrors the approach of a domain expert. The second challenge is that searching for patterns in the relations of a very large network of documents can be very expensive computationally. The proposed solution addresses this by extracting clues from the expert workflow to identify shortcuts that simplify and constrain the larger problem. These clues, combined with sparse expert labeled data can produce a more accurate baseline for optimization of scoring and similarity comparison of larger sets. By being integrated into more workflows, the transparent annotation process and algorithm could be applied to other policy domains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this research project was to improve MonQcle, the legal research software created by Legal Science (LS) to assist the interpretation of legal text using machine learning to help users better understand the law. In this project, we have produced an extendable platform for machine-assisted interpretation specific to the legal domain using a set of machine-learning technologies on expert labeled legal data. The main method of the set of machine-learning technology has been developed to integrate automatic ontology generation into legal experts’ work-flow transparency by capturing the citation, search processes and other patterns in expert analysts’ activities while they interpret legal documents during research/discovery.

As a test-bed, LS has created a public-facing website, named Rabbit Crowd Library (https://rabbit.monqcle.com/). It is a law library that stores and shows state statutes and city ordinances, organized and searchable with the help of machine-learning algorithms. The Rabbit Crowd Library utilized the Natural Language Processing based machine-learning algorithm developed in this project. With the help of these methods, MonQcle users are able to search laws with the topic they specify; they can also be notified when there is a change of  law related to the dataset they have been working on. This technology also enables users to automatically locate the legal text that provides the most relevant answer to their legal question. Moreover, we developed the keyword-search functionality for laws; we built a production level legal text scraping tool that can fetch and clean the legal texts from state statutes. Furthermore, Rabbit Crowd Library is a community and public engagement and discussion platform via like/dislike/comment responses on specific legal text excerpts. It is a social justice, public-facing social network that generates a social impact on legislation. The publicly available legal texts in Rabbit Crowd Library also contribute to resource sharing. The technology we developed in this project also has very high scalability. The dynamic scraping tools, graph-based storage structure and domain-specific supervised learning can support us to extend our work into multiple domains, such as bill tracking, question-answering and document analysis on any documents.

Machine-assisted interpretation has never successfully been accomplished before in the domain of statutory law. Moving the needle on the ability to have the machine interpret law would dramatically reduce the production time of quantitative legal datasets. This project has successfully enabled the possibility for machine-learning technology to make the legal-research related work much more efficient. The targeted users of this technology include traditional legal professionals (firm lawyers, general counsels, paralegals); policy advocates, individuals in corporate policy and regulatory divisions; and citizens who have questions about the state of the law across space and time. This includes multi-state corporations, government agencies, government affairs, non-profit advocacy organizations and educational institutions.
